metadata.synopsis: In 1871 Chicago, honest lawyer Jack (Don Ameche) and his reckless saloon owner brother Dion (Tyrone Power) are two very different men attracted to the same beautiful singer, Belle (Alice Faye). Personally and professionally at odds, their relationship is tested as Jack becomes mayor of Chicago, while his brother becomes a leader in disreputable entertainments. Their conflict culminates in the Great Chicago Fire, started by a cow belonging to their mother, Mrs. O'Leary (Alice Brady).

reviews: ...quite a sociological punch, and a real Chicago flavor. Dirty politics, saloon gangs, slums, tricked elections, fake reform parties. Why old Chicago?
The sincerity of all the actors still surprises. [Full Review in Spanish]
Serious students of the cinema shouldn't miss In Old Chicago. Neither should ordinary folk who like excitement and spectacle and the fun of running after the fire reels.
Chicago makes up in atmosphere and color what it lacks in historical accuracy.
As a film entertainment it is socko.

Zanuck's disaster film, part of cycle that includes Ford's superior Hurricane, is not as entertaining as MGM's San Francisco, but the set-pieces of crowds, riots, and cattle stampedes during the fire are impressive.

With a star-filled cast and a fitful sense of drama, it's pretty much the same old recipe as the equivalent cycle of megabudget '70s exploiters, but the climactic conflagration is certainly worth the wait.
Mr. King's direction, occasionally, is inspired, and the photography has unusual style and dramatic impact.
can't hold our interest for much more than five minutes
Nothing extraordinary in retrospect, but it is genial enough.
Under Henry King's direction there is little of the old Fox pep.
Like San Francisco, events sort of just happen and allegiances just sort of shift around to stall time before the grand finale.
